questions.text: Which of the following structures is most likely to be damaged when the obstetrician observes that the episiotomy performed during a successful delivery has extended posteriorly beyond the perineal body?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) External anal sphincter

Explanation:

The external anal sphincter is a muscular structure that surrounds the anal canal and is responsible for voluntary control of bowel movements. When an episiotomy extends beyond the perineal body, it can result in injury to the external anal sphincter, potentially leading to complications such as fecal incontinence.
The ischiocavernosus muscle (Option B) is located in the perineal region and is involved in the erectile mechanism in males.

The bulbospongiosus muscle (Option C) is also located in the perineal region and plays a role in the erectile mechanism as well as in the expulsion of urine and semen. While it may be involved in the episiotomy, it is less likely to be injured compared to the external anal sphincter.

The urethral sphincter (Option D) is responsible for maintaining urinary continence and is located in close proximity to the vaginal area. While it can be affected during childbirth, an episiotomy extending beyond the perineal body is less likely to directly injure the urethral sphincter.

questions.text: A pregnant woman is undergoing a vaginal breech delivery. After delivering the baby’s body up to the umbilicus, the obstetrician notices winging of the baby’s scapula. To facilitate safe delivery of the baby’s shoulders and head, which of the following maneuvers is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Lovset maneuver

Explanation: In vaginal breech delivery, winging of the scapula indicates that the arms are extended above the head (nuchal arms). The Lovset maneuver is specifically designed to deliver the extended arms by rotating the baby’s body to bring each shoulder anterior under the symphysis pubis, allowing gentle sweeping down of the arms.

Lovset maneuver: In a vaginal breech delivery scenario where one of the baby's arms is extended behind the fetal head, causing difficulty in delivery, the technique typically used to manage this situation is Lovset's manoeuvre.

  • Principle: Due to the curved birth canal, one shoulder remains above the pubic bone while the other is below the sacral promontory. Rotating the fetal trunk with the back anterior and applying downward traction brings the posterior shoulder below the symphysis pubis.
  • Procedure: Lift the baby, induce lateral flexion, rotate the trunk 180° to bring the posterior arm under the pubic arch, and hook out. Rotate the trunk opposite, keeping the back anterior, to deliver the anterior shoulder under the symphysis pubis.

 

 

Pinard's manoeuvre (Option A):

  • This maneuver resolves shoulder dystocia by applying pressure to the anterior shoulder to rotate it internally or manipulate it for delivery.
  • It may be used in some breech deliveries but is not specifically for managing extended arms.

 

Burns Marshall maneuver (Option B):

  • It is used in breech presentation to deliver the after-coming head.
  • The baby hangs by its weight while suprapubic pressure is applied downward and backward.
  • Once the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, the baby's ankles are grasped, and steady traction is applied in an upward and forward arc. Simultaneously, the left hand supports the perineum and guides it gently over the face and brow.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique (Option D) :

The obstetrician supports the baby's head with the palm, and the index finger is placed inside the baby's mouth to support the mandible. Traction is applied to the baby's shoulders to guide the head through the birth canal.

questions.text: In managing shoulder dystocia during vaginal delivery, which of the following is the correct sequence of maneuvers?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) McRoberts → Rubin → Gaskin → Zavanelli

Explanation: The correct sequence is McRoberts → Rubin → Gaskin → Zavanelli because shoulder dystocia is managed with a stepwise escalation from least invasive to most invasive:

Management of Shoulder dystocia:

  1. Call for help – Obstetric, anesthesia, and neonatal teams.
  2. McRoberts maneuver – Hyperflex maternal thighs onto the abdomen to straighten sacrum and rotate pelvis.
  3. Suprapubic pressure – Often combined with McRoberts to dislodge the shoulder.
  4. Rubin maneuver – Pressure on posterior aspect of anterior shoulder to rotate it into the oblique diameter.
  5. Woods corkscrew maneuver – Pressure on anterior aspect of posterior shoulder to aid rotation.
  6. Gaskin maneuver – Mother on all fours to widen pelvic outlet.
  7. Delivery of posterior arm – Reduces shoulder-to-shoulder diameter.
  8. Zavanelli maneuver – Push fetal head back in and proceed to cesarean section (last resort).

questions.text: A 38-week pregnant woman in active labor with 5 cm cervical dilatation and regular contractions suddenly develops umbilical cord prolapse. What is the most appropriate immediate management?

choices.text: Manually elevate the presenting part, fill the bladder retrogradely, and prepare for emergency cesarean section
Perform vaginal packing to protect the cord

questions.solution:
Answer: B. Manually elevate the presenting part, fill the bladder retrogradely, and prepare for emergency cesarean section

Explanation:

Umbilical cord prolapse is an obstetric emergency where the umbilical cord slips ahead of the presenting part, leading to cord compression and acute fetal hypoxia.

First priority: Relieve pressure on the cord to maintain fetal oxygenation until delivery.

  • Manually elevate the presenting part by pushing it upward through the vagina.
  • Fill the bladder retrogradely with warm saline via Foley’s catheter (500–700 mL) to lift the presenting part off the cord.
  • Prepare for emergency cesarean section — definitive management unless imminent vaginal delivery is possible.

The goal of management is to prevent cord compression and restore umbilical blood flow.

  • Positioning: Mother can also be placed in knee-chest or Trendelenburg position.
  • Cord handling: Avoid excessive manipulation to prevent vasospasm.
  • Delivery choice:
    • If cervix fully dilated and head low → expedite vaginal delivery (forceps/vacuum).
      Otherwise → emergency LSCS.
    • Bladder filling is a temporary measure to buy time while preparing for surgery.

Wait and observe (Option A): Dangerous in this scenario as it can lead to irreversible hypoxic brain injury or fetal death. Immediate intervention is required.

Perform vaginal packing to protect the cord (Option C): Not recommended — increases risk of cord compression and infection.

Administer oxytocin to expedite labor (Option D): Stimulating contractions will worsen cord compression and fetal hypoxia. Absolutely contraindicated in cord prolapse until compression is relieved and delivery is planned.

questions.text: A woman sustains a perineal tear during delivery. Examination reveals that less than 50% of the external anal sphincter is involved. Based on the classification system, what is the most appropriate description of this injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Grade 3a

Explanation:

Degrees of perineal tear

Description

First Degree

Injury to perineal skin only.

Second Degree (Option A)

Injury to perineum involving perineal body (muscles) but not involving the anal sphincter.

Third Degree

Injury to perineum, involving the anal sphincter complex (both external and internal):

  • 3a: <50% of EAS thickness torn (Option C)
  • 3b: >50% of EAS thickness torn (Option B)
  • 3c: Both EAS and IAS torn

Fourth degree (Option D)

Injury to perineum involving the anal sphincter complex (EAS and IAS) and anal epithelium.

 

Risk factors of perineal tear:

  • Big baby(weight ≥ 3 kg).
  • Nulliparity.
  • Outlet contraction with narrow pubic arch.
  • Shoulder dystocia.
  • Forceps delivery.
  • Scar in the perineum (perineorrhaphy, episiotomy).
  • Face to pubis delivery.
  • Midline episiotomy.
  • Precipitate labour.

questions.text: During the management of shoulder dystocia in childbirth, which of the following is the earliest and first maneuver typically attempted?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: a- McRoberts maneuver

  • Explanation: The McRoberts maneuver is the first and earliest step in managing shoulder dystocia. It involves hyperflexing the mother’s thighs onto her abdomen, which straightens the lumbosacral angle, rotates the pelvis, and frees the impacted anterior shoulder behind the pubic symphysis.
  • Sequence of events in Shoulder dystocia:
  • Help – call for extra assistance → Evaluate for episiotomy → McRoberts maneuver (first maneuver) → Suprapubic pressure → Rubin maneuver → Woods corkscrew maneuver → Delivery of posterior arm → Roll patient to all fours (Gaskin maneuver) → If unsuccessful, consider cleidotomy, Zavanelli maneuver, or symphysiotomy as last resorts.

Incorrect Options:

Woods corkscrew maneuver (Option B): A rotational maneuver used after McRoberts if initial steps fail; rotates the posterior shoulder anteriorly.

Rubin maneuver (Option C): Also a rotational maneuver, but involves pushing the posterior aspect of the anterior shoulder toward the chest; not the first-line step.

Delivery of posterior arm (Option D): Usually attempted if initial maneuvers (McRoberts + suprapubic pressure) fail; reduces the bisacromial diameter.

questions.text: A patient presents with obstructed labor, and on abdominal examination, a groove or band is palpable across the uterus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Bandl’s ring

Explanation: A Bandl’s ring is an abnormal pathological retraction ring that forms between the upper contractile segment and the lower thin, stretched segment of the uterus during obstructed labor.

  • On abdominal examination, it presents as a palpable transverse or oblique groove running across the uterus. It is associated with prolonged obstructed labor and is a sign of impending uterine rupture if not managed promptly.
 

Bandl's Ring

Schroeder's Ring

(Option B)

Definition

An abnormal ring of constriction that forms in the uterus, typically between the lower and upper uterine segments. It causes an extreme form of uterine atony

A pathological ring of constriction that can occur in any stage of labor, resulting from oxytocin overuse, and may lead to uterine rupture

Cause

Prolonged second stage of labor

Oxytocin overuse, or misuse of uterine stimulants

Stage of Labor

Second stage of labor

Any stage of labor

Management

Cesarean section

Discontinuation of oxytocin, relaxation of the uterus (using tocolytics), and possible cesarean section depending on severity

Constriction ring (Option A): Localized spasm of a small portion of the myometrium, usually around the fetus; not felt as a transverse groove across the abdomen.

Contraction ring (Option C): Normal physiological junction between upper and lower uterine segments; not pathologically elevated or palpable in normal labor.

questions.text: In a case of face presentation during labor, which diameter is seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Submentobregmatic

Explanation:

  • In face presentation, the fetal head is fully extended, and the presenting part is the face with the chin (mentum) as the leading point.
  • The submentobregmatic diameter (9.5 cm) is engaged when mentum is anterior, allowing vaginal delivery.
  • Face presentation occurs due to factors like multiparity, cephalopelvic disproportion, or neck masses.
  • Prognosis depends on chin position: mentum anterior may deliver vaginally; mentum posterior usually requires cesarean.

Face presentation of the fetus

  • Attitude: flexed limbs with extended neck
  • Lie: Longitudinal
  • Presenting part: Face
  • Risk factors
    • Maternal factors
      • Multiparity
      • Lateral obliquity of the uterus
      • Contracted pelvis
      • Pelvic tumors
    • Fetal factors
      • Ananecepathy
      • Congenital goiter
      • Congenital bronchocele
      • Increased tone of extensor neck muscles
  • The engaging diameter depends on the extension of the neck
    • Fully extended head - Submentobregmatic diameter 9.5 cm
    • Partially extended head - Submentovertical 11.5 cm
  • Delivery of the head is achieved by flexion rather than extension like normal vaginal delivery
  • Brow presentation can also convert to face presentation as it is unstable.

 

Incorrect Options:

Mentobregmatic (Option A): This is seen in brow presentation (13.5 cm), where the head is partially extended — largest diameter, leading to obstructed labor.

Suboccipitobregmatic (Option B): Seen in well-flexed vertex presentation — the smallest diameter (9.5 cm) and most favorable for vaginal delivery.

Occipitofrontal (Option C): Seen in deflexed vertex presentation (11.5 cm), more difficult to deliver vaginally.

questions.text: Patient has variable deceleration. What does that indicate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Umbilical cord compression

Explanation:

  • Variable decelerations are abrupt decreases in fetal heart rate with variable timing and shape, often “V” or “W” shaped on CTG.
  • They are most commonly caused by transient umbilical cord compression, leading to sudden changes in fetal circulation.

Variable decelerations:

  • Pathophysiology: Cord compression → brief fetal hypoxia → reflex vagal stimulation → transient FHR drop.
  • Variable decelerations differ from early decelerations (head compression) and late decelerations (placental insufficiency).
  • Management: Maternal position change, amnioinfusion if persistent, treat underlying cause.
  • Severity depends on depth, duration, and frequency of decelerations.

Non-Stress Test (NST):

  • It is a non-invasive test used to assess fetal well-being by monitoring the fetal heart rate and its response to fetal movements.
  • It is typically performed in the third trimester of pregnancy.
  • The mother is placed in a semi-reclining position, and two belts are placed around her abdomen to measure the fetal heart rate and detect fetal movements.

Indications for NST:

  • Post-term pregnancy.
  • Decreased fetal movements.
  • High-risk pregnancies (e.g., hypertension, diabetes).
  • History of previous pregnancy complications.
  • Suspected intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR).

Primary parameters evaluated during an NST:

1. Baseline Fetal Heart Rate (FHR)

2. Beat-to-beat Variability:
  • Normal: 110-160 bpm
  • Bradycardia: less than 110 bpm.
  • Tachycardia: more than 160 bpm.
  • Fluctuations in the heart rate from one beat to the next.
  • Amplitude range of 6-25 bpm (considered normal).

3. Accelerations
  • Temporary increases in FHR above the baseline.
  • Reactive NST:
    • At least two accelerations in a 20-minute period.
    • Each acceleration should be 15 bpm above the baseline and last for at least 15 seconds (for fetuses older than 32 weeks).
  • Non-Reactive NST: Fewer than two accelerations in a 20-minute period.

4. Decelerations

Temporary drops in FHR below the baseline.

  • Early Decelerations: Usually benign, occurring with uterine contractions.
  • Variable Decelerations: Can indicate umbilical cord compression.
  • Late Decelerations: Concerning as they may indicate uteroplacental insufficiency.

5. Fetal Movements
  • The presence and frequency of fetal movements are monitored, as decreased movements can indicate distress.

Interpretation:
  • Reactive NST: Indicative of normal fetal oxygenation and autonomic function.
  • Non-Reactive NST may require further testing, such as a Biophysical Profile (BPP) or Contraction Stress Test (CST).

Incorrect Options:

Fetal head compression (Option B): Causes early decelerations that mirror contractions in timing, not variable in onset or shape.

Uteroplacental insufficiency (Option C): Leads to late decelerations — gradual fall in FHR after contraction peaks, reflecting chronic fetal hypoxia.

Maternal hypotension (Option D): Can cause prolonged decelerations or baseline bradycardia due to decreased uteroplacental blood flow, not the abrupt, variable pattern seen here.

questions.text: Which of the following does not cause fetal bradycardia during labor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Maternal fever

Explanation:

Among the given options, maternal fever does not cause Fetal Bradycardia during labor.

Fetal heart rate (FHR)

  • Normal: 110-160 bpm

Bradycardia

(<110 bpm)

Tachycardia

(>160 bpm)
  • Congenital heart block (m/c) (Option D ruled out)
  • Prolonged cord compression
  • Cord prolapse
  • Tetanic uterine contractions
  • Paracervical block
  • Serious fetal compromise
  • Maternal fever (Option A)
  • Fetal hypoxia
  • Fetal anemia
  • Amnionitis

 

 

Acceleration

Deceleration

  • Temporary increases in FHR above the baseline.
  • Reactive NST:
    • At least two accelerations in a 20-minute period.
    • Each acceleration should be 15 bpm above the baseline and last for at least 15 seconds (for fetuses older than 32 weeks).
  • Non-Reactive NST: Fewer than two accelerations in a 20-minute period.
  • Indicates:
    • Healthy fetus with intact neurohormonal and cardiovascular function.

Temporary drops in FHR below the baseline.

  • Early Decelerations: Usually benign, occurring with uterine contractions.
    • Fetal head compression (Option B ruled out)
  • Variable Decelerations:
    • Umbilical cord compression
  • Late Decelerations:
    • Fetal hypoxia
    • Uteroplacental insufficiency (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 34-year-old G2P1L1 presents with abdominal pain, bleeding per vaginum in labor, and loss of fetal movements. She occasionally smokes but does not consume alcohol or recreational drugs. On examination, her pulse rate is 80 bpm, BP is 150/90 mmHg, and her abdomen is tense on palpation. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Abruptio placenta

Explanation:

  • Abruptio placenta, or placental abruption, is the premature separation of the placenta from the uterine wall before delivery.
  • Abruptio placenta is a form of antepartum haemorrhage, where the bleeding occurs due to premature separation of the normally situated placenta.

Pathogenesis:

  • Bleeding occurs due to rupture of blood vessels in the decidua basalis.
  • There is an accumulation of blood in the decidua.
  • This causes the separation of the placenta, leading to
    • Further bleeding.
    • Thrombin generation from haemorrhage triggers the action of matrix metalloproteinases, inflammatory cytokines, and coagulation cascade (high risk of DIC).
    • Fetal distress.

Clinical features:

  • Mild to moderate vaginal bleeding
  • Abdominal pain
  • Uterine tenderness
  • Back pain
  • Fetal distress
  • Hypovolemic shock
  • Frequent contractions

Types of abruptio placenta:

Revealed

  • Most common type, where the bleeding from the placental detachment is visible and exits through the vagina.
  • This is often associated with vaginal bleeding and abdominal pain.

Concealed

  • Bleeding is hidden behind the placenta and is not visible externally.
  • Blood collects within the uterus, causing increased pressure and pain without visible bleeding.

Mixed

  • Involves both concealed and revealed bleeding.
  • There is both internal and external bleeding, with some blood exiting through the vagina and some collecting behind the placenta.

Page Classification of abruptio placentae:

Grade

Maternal findings

Fetal findings

0
  • Clinical features may be absent.
  • The diagnosis is made after inspection of the placenta following delivery.

1

Bleeding PV + Abdominal pain
(Uterine tenderness ±)

Fetal heart sounds are normal

2

Bleeding PV + Abdominal pain
(Uterine tenderness always +)

Fetal distress

3

Bleeding PV + Abdominal pain (marked uterine tenderness) + Shock ± Coagulopathy

Fetal death

 

Comparison of findings in placenta previa and abruptio placentae:

 

Placenta previa

Abruptio placentae

Clinical features

Nature of bleeding

Painless, causeless, and recurrent.

Painful, often attributed to Pre-eclampsia or trauma, and continuous.

Character of blood

Bleeding is always revealed.

Revealed, concealed, or usually mixed.

General condition & anaemia

Proportionate to visible blood loss.

Out of proportion to the visible blood loss in the concealed or mixed variety.

Features of eclampsia

Not relevant.

Present in one-third of the cases.

Abdominal examination

Height of the uterus

Proportionate height to the gestational age.

It may be disproportionately enlarged in concealed type.

The feel of the uterus

Soft and relaxed.

It may be tense, tender, and rigid.

Malpresentation

Common (the head is high floating).

Unrelated, the head may be engaged.

Fetal heart sounds

Usually present.

Usually absent, especially in the concealed type.

USG, MRI

Placenta in the lower segment.

Placenta in the upper segment.

Vaginal examination

The placenta is felt on the lower segment (not to be done in a suspected case).

The placenta is not felt on the lower segment. Blood clots should not be confused with placenta.

 

Placenta previa (Option B) occurs when the placenta covers the cervix partially or completely. It typically presents with painless vaginal bleeding in the third trimester and no abdominal pain or tense uterus, making it unlikely in this scenario.

Hydramnios (polyhydramnios) (Option C) is an excessive accumulation of amniotic fluid. It may cause abdominal discomfort or uterine distension but does not present with vaginal bleeding, loss of fetal movements, or a tense abdomen.

Preterm labor (Option D) involves uterine contractions before 37 weeks of gestation. While it may cause abdominal pain, it is not associated with vaginal bleeding, tense abdomen, or loss of fetal movements in the absence of other complications.

questions.text: A 23-year-old G3 P1L1 A1 at 37 weeks of gestation with a previous history of emergency caesarean section and dilatation and curettage presents to the ER with labor pains. During abdominal examination, it was difficult to palpate fetal parts. Per vaginal examination revealed a 5 cm dilated cervix, and her vitals were: BP-80/60 mmHg, RR – 20/min, HR – 106/min, SpO2 – 97% on room air. CTG showed a non-reassuring variable fetal heart rate pattern. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Placental abruption

Explanation:

  • Placental abruption involves partial or complete detachment of the placenta from the uterine wall before delivery. This leads to severe abdominal pain, difficult palpation of fetal parts, hypotension, tachycardia, and non-reassuring fetal heart patterns, as seen in this patient.
  • Abruptio placenta is a form of antepartum haemorrhage, where the bleeding occurs due to premature separation of the normally situated placenta.

Pathogenesis:

  • Bleeding occurs due to rupture of blood vessels in the decidua basalis.
  • There is an accumulation of blood in the decidua.
  • This causes the separation of the placenta, leading to
    • Further bleeding.
    • Thrombin generation from haemorrhage triggers the action of matrix metalloproteinases, inflammatory cytokines, and coagulation cascade (high risk of DIC).
    • Fetal distress.

Clinical features:

  • Mild to moderate vaginal bleeding
  • Abdominal pain
  • Uterine tenderness
  • Back pain
  • Fetal distress
  • Hypovolemic shock
  • Frequent contractions

Types of abruptio placenta:

Revealed

  • Most common type, where the bleeding from the placental detachment is visible and exits through the vagina.
  • This is often associated with vaginal bleeding and abdominal pain.

Concealed

  • Bleeding is hidden behind the placenta and is not visible externally.
  • Blood collects within the uterus, causing increased pressure and pain without visible bleeding.

Mixed

  • Involves both concealed and revealed bleeding.
  • There is both internal and external bleeding, with some blood exiting through the vagina and some collecting behind the placenta.

 

 

Page Classification of abruptio placentae:

Grade

Maternal findings

Fetal findings

0
  • Clinical features may be absent.
  • The diagnosis is made after inspection of the placenta following delivery.

1

Bleeding PV + Abdominal pain
(Uterine tenderness ±)

Fetal heart sounds are normal

2

Bleeding PV + Abdominal pain
(Uterine tenderness always +)

Fetal distress

3

Bleeding PV + Abdominal pain (marked uterine tenderness) + Shock ± Coagulopathy

Fetal death

 

Comparison of findings in placenta previa and abruptio placentae:

 

Placenta previa

Abruptio placentae

Clinical features

Nature of bleeding

Painless, causeless, and recurrent.

Painful, often attributed to Pre-eclampsia or trauma, and continuous.

Character of blood

Bleeding is always revealed.

Revealed, concealed, or usually mixed.

General condition & anaemia

Proportionate to visible blood loss.

Out of proportion to the visible blood loss in the concealed or mixed variety.

Features of eclampsia

Not relevant.

Present in one-third of the cases.

Abdominal examination

Height of the uterus

Proportionate height to the gestational age.

It may be disproportionately enlarged in concealed type.

The feel of the uterus

Soft and relaxed.

It may be tense, tender, and rigid.

Malpresentation

Common (the head is high floating).

Unrelated, the head may be engaged.

Fetal heart sounds

Usually present.

Usually absent, especially in the concealed type.

USG, MRI

Placenta in the lower segment.

Placenta in the upper segment.

Vaginal examination

The placenta is felt on the lower segment (not to be done in a suspected case).

The placenta is not felt on the lower segment. Blood clots should not be confused with placenta.

 

Amniotic fluid embolism (Option A) typically presents with respiratory distress and cardiovascular collapse, not consistent with the described findings.

Uterine rupture (Option C) causes severe pain and maternal shock but is less likely here, given the clinical presentation.

Placenta previa (Option D) usually presents with painless bleeding rather than severe abdominal pain and abnormal fetal heart rate patterns.

questions.text: Identify the type of pelvis shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Anthropoid pelvis

Explanation:

  • The anthropoid pelvis is characterized by an oval shape with a longer anteroposterior diameter and a narrower transverse diameter. This type of pelvis is commonly associated with a favorable outcome for vaginal delivery, particularly when the baby is in the face-to-pubis position.

Pelvic Types

Feature

Gynecoid

(Option A)

Android

(Option C)

Anthropoid

Platypelloid

(Option D)

Shape

Round or slightly oval

Heart-shaped

Oval (anteroposterior)

Flattened oval (transverse)

Prevalence

Most common (~50%)

~20%

~25%

Rare (~5%)

Description
  • Transversely oval pelvic inlet
  • Broad, shallow sacrum
  • Blunt, widely spaced ischial spines
  • Wide subpubic angle (>90°)
  • Triangular or heart-shaped pelvic inlet
  • Flat, forward-inclined sacrum
  • Prominent, closely spaced ischial spines
  • Narrow subpubic angle (<70°)
  • Oval pelvic inlet (anteroposterior > transverse)
  • Long, narrow sacrum
  • Less prominent, widely spaced ischial spines
  • Narrow subpubic angle (~70°)
  • Wide, flat pelvic inlet (transverse > anteroposterior)
  • Short, flat sacrum
  • Blunt, widely spaced ischial spines
  • Wide subpubic angle (>90°)

Obstetric Significance
  • Ideal for vaginal delivery due to spacious cavity and optimal dimensions
  • Increased risk of obstructed labor
  • Associated with deep transverse arrest
  • Favors occipito-posterior fetal positions
  • Vaginal delivery usually possible
  • Delayed engagement of the fetal head
  • Higher likelihood of cesarean delivery

questions.text: It is shoulder dystocia when the anterior shoulder is delivered after what time of head delivery?
questions.solution:
Shoulder dystocia occurs when the anterior (common) or posterior (rare) shoulder impacts the maternal symphysis pubis or sacral promontory.

  • ACOG Definition: Shoulder dystocia requires maneuvers beyond gentle traction to deliver the shoulders.
  • Spong et al. Criteria: Head-to-body delivery time >60 seconds or the need for ancillary obstetric maneuvers (McRoberts, suprapubic pressure, rotational maneuvers, or hands’ and knees’ positioning).

 

Key Indicator: Turtle sign (fetal head retracting against the perineum), often due to umbilical cord compression, making it an obstetric emergency.

 

Risk Factors:

  • History of shoulder dystocia
  • Macrosomia (>4.5 kg), Diabetes, Obesity (BMI >30)
  • Induced labor, Prolonged/Arrested labor
  • Postmaturity, Multiparity, Mid-pelvic instrumental delivery
  • Fetal ascites, Anencephaly


 

Complications:

Maternal Complications

Neonatal Complications
  • Soft tissue injuries: Lacerations of the bladder, urethra, vagina, anal sphincter, or rectum
  • Nerve injury: Lateral femoral cutaneous neuropathy
  • Postpartum hemorrhage
  • Pelvic injury: Symphyseal separation
  • Uterine rupture
  • Fetal death
  • Hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE)
  • Fractures: Clavicle or humerus
  • Neurologic injuries:
    • Brachial plexus injury
    • Diaphragmatic paralysis
    • Facial nerve injury
    • Horner syndrome (ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis)

 

Management of Shoulder dystocia:

  1. Avoid fundal pressure (worsens impaction).
  2. Perform maneuvers sequentially:
    • McRoberts maneuver: Involves hyperflexing and abducting the maternal thighs onto the abdomen, which rotates the symphysis pubis upward, straightens the sacrum, and increases the pelvic outlet, facilitating shoulder delivery.
    • Suprapubic pressure: Applied downward and laterally; it helps reduce the bisacromial diameter and rotates the anterior shoulder toward the oblique pelvic diameter, facilitating shoulder descent.
    • Wood’s corkscrew maneuver: Involves rotating the posterior shoulder 180° to the anterior using two fingers in the posterior vagina while applying simultaneous suprapubic pressure to aid entry into the pelvis.
    • Delivery of posterior arm: The operator introduces a hand into the vagina, sweeps the posterior arm across the chest, and delivers it with gentle traction, reducing the shoulder width but potentially causing fractures.
    • All-Fours (Gaskin) maneuver: The mother is placed on all fours, which increases the pelvic dimensions and allows the fetal position to shift, making it easier to apply downward traction to free the impacted shoulder.
  3. Last-resort interventions (if all fail):
    • Cleidotomy: Deliberate fracture of the clavicle using finger pressure or scissors to reduce shoulder width, performed in extreme cases when other maneuvers fail.
    • Zavanelli maneuver: Involves pushing the fetal head back into the uterus followed by emergency C-section, used as a last resort when vaginal delivery is impossible.
    • Symphysiotomy: To widen the pelvis. Rarely done, in extreme cases where all other options fail

questions.text: At what point of cervical dilatation should a nursing assistant in the obstetric care unit begin plotting a paragraph to track labor progress?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 4cm

Explanation:

  • A partograph is a graphical tool used to monitor the progress of labor. It helps healthcare providers track cervical dilatation, the descent of the presenting part, and other vital parameters during labor. The graph is divided into different sections, and plotting begins at a specific point in cervical dilatation.
  • According to the standard practice, plotting on the partograph should start when the cervix is dilated at 4cm. This is considered the active phase of labor when regular contractions and progressive cervical dilation are expected. Starting the plot at 4cm allows for the assessment of the labor progress and helps identify any deviations or abnormalities that may require intervention.

 

2 cm dilation (Option A) indicates the early phase of labor, not yet active, where contractions are irregular, making it unsuitable for accurate monitoring of active labor.

Delaying plotting until 7 cm dilation (Option C) may result in missed opportunities for early detection of labor abnormalities.

While 6 cm dilatation (Option D) is within the active phase of labor, it is recommended to begin at 4 cm for more comprehensive monitoring of labor progress.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the management of a woman in labour with a planned vaginal breech delivery is incorrect?

choices.text: Breech identified for the first time during delivery is a contraindication for normal delivery
Breech delivery is done in a hospital where a facility for emergency cesarean delivery is available
Continuous FHR monitoring is required for breech delivery during labour
Should be done by a skilled obstetrician

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Breech identified for the first time during delivery is a contraindication for normal delivery

Explanation:

  • While a breech presentation (where the baby is positioned bottom-first instead of head-first) does increase the complexity and potential risks associated with vaginal delivery, it is not an absolute contraindication for normal vaginal delivery. In some cases, a breech presentation may be diagnosed for the first time during labor, and a skilled obstetrician may decide that a vaginal breech delivery can still be safely attempted.

 

Breech deliveries should indeed be performed in a hospital where a facility for emergency cesarean delivery is available, as complications can arise during labor. (Option B ruled out)

Continuous fetal heart rate (FHR) monitoring is essential during breech delivery (Option C ruled out) due to the increased risk of fetal distress, ensuring the well-being of the baby.

A vaginal breech delivery must be managed by a skilled obstetrician (Option D ruled out)with specialized training, as breech deliveries require careful handling to prevent injury to the baby and mother.

questions.text: During an examination of a woman in labor, a midwife observes a prolapsed cord. What is the immediate next step in managing this situation?

choices.text: Gently replace the cord inside the vagina
Inform the doctor and shift to OT
Do vaginal examination and find the fetal presentation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Put her in Trendelenberg position

Explanation:

  • The Trendelenburg position (lying on the back with legs elevated higher than the head) would cause gravity to shift the fetus upwards into the uterine cavity, away from the prolapsed cord allowing pressure to be relieved. This would be the best immediate next action to be done by the midwife.

 

In case of a prolapsed cord, the healthcare provider should be informed immediately, and the woman should be taken to the operating theatre (OT) for an emergency cesarean section (Option B). This is to ensure a quick delivery and avoid further compression of the cord. A prolapsed umbilical cord is a medical emergency that occurs when the umbilical cord slips down into the birth canal ahead of the baby. This can potentially cut off the baby's oxygen supply, and immediate action is required. In the above scenario mentioned in the question, the next best management would be the change in position.

Attempting to push the cord back inside the vagina (Option A) can compress it further, leading to decreased blood flow to the baby. This should not be done.

While it's important to know the fetal presentation (Option D), in the case of a prolapsed cord, the priority is to inform the doctor and initiate immediate management, which usually involves a cesarean section to deliver the baby promptly.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman, on examination, was found to have infra-umbilical flattening. The fetal heart sounds were heard over the lateral side. What could be the fetal presentation/ position?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Occipitoposterior

Explanation: The fetal presentation/position is likely Occipitoposterior, as infra-umbilical flattening and lateral fetal heart tones suggest a posterior fetal position.

Occipito-posterior (OP):

  • Occurs when the occiput is located posteriorly, either over the sacroiliac joint or directly above the sacrum, with the fetus in a vertex presentation.
  • Clinical findings:
    • Inspection: Flattening of the abdomen below the umbilicus, known as infra-umbilical flattening, may be observed.
    • Pelvic examination: Fetal head is not engaged, and the sinciput (cephalic prominence) is not easily palpable.
    • Auscultation: Fetal heart tones are typically heard over the flanks, but in the direct OP position, they are heard in the midline.
  • Variants of OP position:
    • Left OP position: The occiput is directed towards the left sacroiliac joint (fourth vertex position).
    • Right OP position: The occiput faces the right sacroiliac joint, which is more common than the left OP position (third vertex position).
    • Direct OP position: The occiput points directly towards the sacrum.

Brow (Option A): In a brow presentation, the fetal head is partially extended, presenting the brow. This position, with a larger head diameter, does not align with infra-umbilical flattening and lateral fetal heart tones, which are more typical of an occipitoposterior position.

Knee (Option B): In a knee presentation, one or both fetal knees are present at the maternal pelvis. This rare presentation is not consistent with infra-umbilical flattening and lateral fetal heart tones, which are more typical of an occipitoposterior position.

Right dorso-anterior (Option D): In a right dorso-anterior presentation, the fetus lies transversely with the back towards the anterior, causing a wide abdomen and the head and breech to be felt in opposite iliac fossae, which occurs in a transverse lie.

questions.text: A primigravida is in labour. Her per-vaginal examination revealed a posterior cervix with 5 cm cervical length, 1 cm dilatation, soft consistency, and head at -1 station. Calculate the modified Bishop score.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 5

Explanation: The Modified Bishop score of the given patient is calculated to be 5.

Based on the given information:

  • Cervical dilation: 1 cm → 1 point
  • Cervical length: 5 cm→ 0 points
  • Cervical consistency: Soft → 2 points
  • Position: Posterior → 0 points
  • Fetal station: -1 → 2 point

Total Score = 1 (dilation) + 0 (cervical length) + 2 (consistency) + 0 (position) + 2 (station) = 5

Modified Bishop score is calculated as:

Criteria

0 Points

1 Point

2 Points

3 Points

Dilation (cm)

Closed

1-2

3-4

≥5

Cervical length

4 cm

2-4 cm

1-2 cm

<1cm

Station

-3

-2

-1, 0

+1, +2

Consistency

Firm

Medium

Soft

 

Position

Posterior

Mid position

Anterior

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Total Score: The sum of points from all five criteria.

Interpretation:

  • ≤6: Unfavorable cervix (Cervical ripening agents may be necessary)
  • ≥9: Favorable cervix for induction (high likelihood of successful induction)

questions.text: All of the following are the diagnostic criteria for preterm labor except?

choices.text: 4 contractions in 20 minutes and 8 contractions in 60 minutes with changes in the cervix.

Cervical dilatation > 2 cm.
More than 80 percent effaced cervix.
Cervix posterior in position.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Cervix posterior in position.

 

Explanation:

The diagnostic criteria for preterm labor (PTL) do not include a posterior cervix as a defining feature.

  • A posterior cervix is typically associated with a lower Bishop’s score and indicates a lower likelihood of preterm labor.
  • On the other hand, a cervix in the anterior or midline position is associated with a higher likelihood of preterm labor, as these positions favor cervical dilation and effacement.

 

Diagnostic Criteria for Preterm Labor:

 

  1. Contractions: Regular uterine contractions occurring at least once every 10 minutes, or 4 contractions in 20 minutes, or 8 contractions in 60 minutes, with or without pain. (Option A ruled out)
  2. Cervical Changes:
    • Cervical dilation > 2 cm. (Option B ruled out)
    • Cervical effacement > 80%. (Option C ruled out)
    • Cervical length (on TVS) < 2.6 cm.
    • Funneling of the internal os > 1 cm.
  3. Symptoms: Pelvic pressure, backache, vaginal discharge, or bleeding per vaginum.

 

Predictors of Preterm Labor:

 

Clinical predictors:

  • History of prior preterm birth.
  • Multiple pregnancies.
  • Active genital tract infection.

 

Biophysical predictors:

  • Uterine contractions >24/hour.
  • Bishop score >4.
  • Cervical length <25 mm on transvaginal ultrasound.

 

Biochemical predictors:

  • Positive fetal fibronectin (fFN) (>60 ng/mL) in cervico-vaginal discharge.
  • Elevated levels of IL-6, IL-8, and TNF-alpha.

Modified Bishop's Score:

Parameter

Score 0

Score 1

Score 2

Score 3

Cervical Dilation

Closed or ≤1 cm

2-3 cm

4-5 cm

≥6 cm

Cervical Effacement

0-30%

40-50%

60-70%

≥80%

Fetal Station

-3 (high)

-2 (presenting part at ischial spines)

-1 to 0 (at the level of the ischial spines)

+1 to +2 (below the ischial spines)

Cervical Consistency

Firm

Medium

Soft

Very soft

Cervical Position

Posterior

Mid-position

Anterior

Very anterior

 

Total Score Interpretation:

  • Score 0-3: Unfavorable for labor induction.
  • Score 4-5: Fairly favorable for labor induction.

Score 6 or above: Favorable for labor induction and higher chances of successful vaginal delivery.

questions.text: In a 35-year-old pregnant woman at 32 weeks of gestation, which of the following conditions is oxytocin contraindicated for?

choices.text: Induction of labor in post-term pregnancy
Augmentation of labor in case of slow progress
Preterm labor with cervical dilation of 3 cm

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Placenta covering internal os

Explanation:

  • Placenta previa, where the placenta partially or completely covers the internal os, is a contraindication for oxytocin use. In this condition, inducing or augmenting labor with oxytocin can lead to severe bleeding.

Oxytocin:

  • Indications:
    • Antepartum Indications (FDA-approved):
      • For mothers with preeclampsia, maternal diabetes, or premature rupture of membranes.
      • For mothers with an inactive uterus requiring stimulation to start labor.
      • For inevitable or incomplete abortions in the second trimester.
    • Postpartum Indications (FDA-approved):
      • To help deliver the placenta during the third stage of labor.
      • To control postpartum hemorrhage.
    • Non-FDA-approved Indications:
      • Treatment of delayed orgasm.
      • Inducing sexual arousal.
      • Treatment of autism (potential role in improving social skills but requires further studies).
  • Contraindications:
    • Hypersensitivity
    • Contraindications for Vaginal Deliveries:
      • Active genital herpes infection.
      • Vasa previa (blood vessels in the membranes).
      • Placenta previa.
      • Invasive cervical cancer.
      • Prolapse or presentation of the umbilical cord.
    • Fetal Abnormalities:
      • Fetus in an abnormal position, such as transverse lie.
      • Fetal distress when delivery is not imminent.
    • Pelvic and Uterine Issues:
      • Inadequate pelvic size for vaginal delivery.
      • Hyperactive or hypertonic uterus.
         

Induction of labor in post-term pregnancy (Option B): Oxytocin is commonly used for labor induction in post-term pregnancies (beyond 40 weeks). It helps initiate contractions and progress labor safely, making it an appropriate choice in this scenario.

Augmentation of labor in case of slow progress (Option C): Oxytocin is frequently used to augment labor when progress is slow. By strengthening contractions, it helps move labor forward effectively. Unless contraindications like placenta previa or fetal distress are present, this is a standard and appropriate use of oxytocin.

Preterm labor with cervical dilation of 3 cm (Option D): In cases of preterm labor, oxytocin may be used to enhance contractions and ensure labor progresses safely, especially when delivery is inevitable. A cervical dilation of 3 cm indicates that labor has started, and oxytocin could be considered for augmentation if deemed safe by the healthcare provider.

questions.text: A 28-year-old G1P0 woman has been pushing for 2 hours with minimal progression. The obstetrician is considering outlet forceps assistance. On examination, the fetal head is visible at the vaginal opening. Outlet forceps are applied at which station?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Head on perineum

Explanation: Head on Perineum typically corresponds to station +5, where the fetal head is visible at the vaginal opening and ready for delivery. Outlet forceps are appropriate at this stage.

Operative Vaginal Delivery Prerequisites and Classification According to Station and Rotation:

 

Procedure

Criteria

Outlet forceps
  • Scalp is visible at the introitus without separating the labia
  • Fetal skull has reached pelvic floor
  • Fetal head is at or on perineum
  • Head is OA or OP or
  • Head is right or left OA or OP position but rotation ≤45 degrees

Low forceps (2 types)
  • Fetal station is ≥+2 cm but not on the pelvic floor, and:
  • (a) Rotation ≤45 degrees is required or
  • (b) Rotation >45 degrees is required

Midforceps
  • Fetal station is between 0 and +2 cm

Prerequisites
  • Engaged head
  • Vertex presentation
  • Known fetal head position
  • CPD not suspected
  • Fetal weight estimated
  • Experienced operator
  • Ruptured membranes
  • Completely dilated cervix
  • Adequate anesthesia
  • Emptied maternal bladder
  • No fetal coagulopathy
  • No fetal demineralization disorder
  • Informed consent completed
  • Willingness to abandon OVD

CPD = cephalopelvic disproportion; OA = occiput anterior; OP = occiput posterior; OVD = operative vaginal delivery.

Head 1/5th palpable per abdomen (Option A): This indicates that the fetal head is still significantly above the pelvic outlet, making it unsafe for outlet forceps application. At this level, the head is too high for outlet forceps, which could result in maternal or fetal trauma.

0 station (Option B): At this level, the fetal head is at the ischial spines, which is too high for outlet forceps. This position would require mid-cavity rather than outlet forceps if operative delivery is needed.

Station +2 (Option C): While this indicates descent below the ischial spines, it is still not advanced enough for outlet forceps. Outlet forceps require the head to be visible at the introitus with perineal distention.

questions.text: A 34-year-old G2P1 woman at 41 weeks gestation is in active labor. She has a history of gestational diabetes and her previous baby weighed 4.2 kg. During delivery, the fetal head delivers normally, but afterward, despite gentle traction, the shoulders fail to deliver. During delivery, the head is delivered, but the shoulders become stuck. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Shoulder Dystocia

Explanation:

  • Shoulder dystocia occurs when the fetal shoulders fail to deliver shortly after the head has emerged, despite gentle pulling. This condition is typically diagnosed if the shoulders do not deliver within 60 seconds after the head.

  • Normal Delivery Time: Under normal circumstances, the shoulders should deliver within 20-25 seconds after the fetal head.

  • Incidence: Occurs in approximately 1% of all deliveries and can lead to significant neonatal morbidity and mortality.

  • Risk Factors:

    • Large babies (macrosomia) > 4 kg

    • Post-term pregnancy

    • Diabetic mothers

    • Anencephaly (due to absence of pituitary function leading to delayed labor onset and larger babies)

Cephalopelvic Disproportion (CPD) (Option A) occurs when the baby's head or body is too large to fit through the mother's pelvis. It is typically diagnosed before or during labor due to the lack of progress in labor rather than after the head is delivered.

Occipito-posterior Position (Option B) While occipito-posterior positioning can lead to a longer and more difficult labor but is not characterized by the shoulders getting stuck after the head is delivered.

Breech presentation (Option D) occurs when the baby is positioned with the buttocks or feet first rather than the head. This is identified before delivery and managed differently. It does not involve the head being delivered first followed by stuck shoulders.

questions.text: A 28-year-old G2P1 presents in active labor at 39 weeks gestation. On examination, the fetus is in occiput posterior (OP) position with reassuring fetal heart tones. She had a previous uncomplicated vaginal delivery. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Proceed with normal vaginal delivery

Explanation:Occiput posterior (OP) position, while a malposition, does not automatically necessitate surgical intervention. Normal vaginal delivery should be attempted first in the absence of other complications.

  • OP position occurs in approximately 10% of vertex presentations
  • Most OP positions can successfully deliver vaginally
  • Fetal heart tones are typically heard more centrally due to fetal back position
  • Previous successful vaginal delivery is a positive prognostic factor

External cephalic version (Option C): External cephalic version (ECV) is a procedure that turns a breech baby into a head-down position. This procedure is used for breech presentations, not for OP position.

Immediate cesarean section (Option B): Not indicated for OP position. This would be overly aggressive management when vaginal delivery is often successful.

Forceps rotation (Option D): Should not be the initial management. It should only be considered if there's failure to progress after attempting vaginal delivery.

questions.text: Which of the following is the next appropriate step in management after the failure of the McRobert maneuver in a case of shoulder dystocia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Suprapubic pressure

Explanation:

  • Shoulder dystocia occurs when shoulders fail to deliver with easy pulling within 60 seconds after delivery of the fetal head
  • Suprapubic pressure (also known as Rubin's maneuver) is applied if the McRoberts maneuver fails to deliver the shoulders
  • Suprapubic pressure can release an impacted anterior shoulder

 

Woods maneuver (Option A): This rotational maneuver is performed after failed suprapubic pressure, not immediately after McRoberts. The Woods maneuver involves rotating the posterior shoulder 180 degrees toward the fetal back and is considered a third-line intervention.

Gaskin maneuver (Option B): Moving the mother to all-fours position is attempted after failure of anterior maneuvers. While effective, it requires time to reposition the mother and is not the immediate next step after McRoberts failure.

Zavanelli maneuver (Option D): This is a last-resort emergency procedure involving cephalic replacement followed by cesarean delivery. It carries significant fetal and maternal morbidity and is only considered when all other maneuvers have failed.
